back.definition: Length > complexity. NIST: 8+ chars minimum, 64+ max. No forced rotation (causes weak patterns). Allow spaces, special chars. Check against breach lists.
back.example: Correct: 'my dog has fleas 2024'. Incorrect: 'P@ssw0rd1' (predictable). Use password managers. Diceware passphrases.

back.definition: Store passwords encrypted. Generate random passwords. Autofill. Master password + MFA protection. Enterprise: 1Password, LastPass, Bitwarden.
back.example: User memorizes 1 strong master password. Manager generates unique 20-char random per site. Prevents credential stuffing.

back.definition: Attacker usa leaked credentials from site A para try en site B. Password reuse = vulnerability. Automated at scale.
back.example: LinkedIn breach → attackers try same email/password en banks. Defense: Unique passwords per site, MFA, CAPTCHA, rate limiting.

back.definition: Eliminate passwords entirely. FIDO2/passkeys, biometrics, magic links. Microsoft: 200M users passwordless. Reduces phishing, improves UX.
back.example: Passkeys (Apple/Google): Device generates key pair. Private key never leaves device. Phishing-resistant. WebAuthn standard.

unlock_content.title: Strength Metrics
points: Length: 12+ chars recommended. 16+ for critical accounts.
Entropy: Random > Dictionary words. 'correct horse battery staple' = 44 bits entropy.
Avoid: Personal info, keyboard patterns (qwerty), common substitutions (@ for a).
Test: HaveIBeenPwned, zxcvbn library for strength estimation.
Gold standard: Password manager generated 20+ random chars.
unlock_content.bonus_fact: 8-char all-lowercase: 2 seconds to crack. 12-char mixed: 300+ years at current GPU speeds.

unlock_content.title: MFA Deployment
points: Method: FIDO2 > TOTP > SMS (better than nothing)
Recovery codes: Store securely. Needed if device lost.
unlock_content.bonus_fact: Microsoft: MFA blocks 99.9% of automated attacks. 0.1% is sophisticated phishing/MFA bypass.

content.question: Mejor práctica para passwords según NIST guidelines?

options.feedback: Incorrecto. NIST eliminó forced rotation requirement. Causa: Users crean weak patterns (Password1 → Password2).

options.text: Length > complexity. Check breach lists. No forced rotation. MFA obligatorio.
options.feedback: CORRECTO! NIST SP 800-63B: 1) 8+ chars minimum (length). 2) No complexity requirements que causan weak patterns. 3) Check against breach databases (HaveIBeenPwned). 4) No forced periodic rotation. 5) Allow paste (para password managers). 6) MFA mandatory. Focus: User behavior > arbitrary rules.

options.text: Passwords deben tener mayúsculas, números, símbolos
options.feedback: Incorrecto. Complexity rules causan predictable patterns: 'Password1!'. Length es más importante. 'my dog has fleas' > 'P@ssw0rd'.
